newsitem.title: USA: Life more comfortable aboard Mir, says NASA.
newsitem.headline: Life more comfortable aboard Mir, says NASA.

text.p: A crucial stabilisation system aboard Russia's Mir space station was close to reactivation on Sunday and life aboard the damaged orbital outpost was slowly improving, NASA officials said.

Five spinning gyrodyne devices used to maintain the position of the sprawling Mir complex were reactivated and a sixth was expected to be operating soon, said Frank Culbertson, the veteran astronaut who oversees NASA's missions to Mir.

The restoration of the positional pointing system will be a major milestone on the station's road to recovery. Since Wednesday's collision with an unmanned cargo craft, the station has been using fuel-hungry rocket thrusters to stabilise its position.
Mir's three-man crew had a lighter work schedule on Sunday and appeared in good spirits in television pictures released by NASA.

"What you are seeing is a reduction in the adrenaline level," Culbertson told a news conference. "What you have is a slowly increasing level of comfort on board and on the ground that things are returning to more normal operations."
Mir commander Vasili Tsibliev and engineer Alexander Lazutkin had opportunities to chat with their families. NASA's Michael Foale was expected to talk with his wife later on Sunday.
Culbertson lauded the efforts of the Mir crew. Tsibliev and Lazutkin were also aboard the station during a serious fire and had to contend with numerous mechanical breakdowns.
"These guys are real heroes," he said. "It's been a serious situation here. They have remained calm and they have handled it very well."
"We're alive, thank God," Tsibliev said on Sunday during a brief exchange with flight controllers at the Russian mission control near Moscow.
The Russian space authorities continued to draw up plans for a daring six- to seven-hour spacewalk inside the station to regain power from the crash-damaged module.
Repair gear was to be shipped to the Russian launch site in Kazakhstan on Monday for launch aboard a cargo ship between July 5 and 8. The supplies should arrive at Mir two days later.
